body: Again rebased to current master to resolve the merge error :sweat:. Hopefully we can get this long pending PR merged this week!
PG1 2788 üîµ

@markusthoemmes To answer your question above - yes, this change caches attachments in the controller as well. @chetanmeh mentioned in Slack that he'd like to followup on this change with another set of changes to cache attachments only in the Invoker and to store cached attachments on the filesystem instead of JVM heap.

That second point - the fact that caches are stored in the heap - would be my only other concern in merging this patch. For environments with a limited number of functions this change isn't a big deal. But, if your OpenWhisk installation has many thousands of different functions that get invoked within the current 5 minute cache timeout then this may be an issue.

Until or unless we test filesystem-based attachment caching, we may want to set a `maximumWeight` or `maximumSize` on the `Caffeine` cache instances so that cached attachments get evicted before relying on the JVM garbage collection of soft references and/or expiration time.

In my opinion, the performance improvement for Java functions under load is worth figuring out these other details.

Speaking of performance improvements, I thought I'd share some basic throughput numbers here. On my test cluster with a simple Hello World Java action I was only able to sustain about 25 action activations per second across the entire cluster before this change. Afterwards, I was able to sustain about 410 action activations per second. The Invoker load, end-user activation latency, and waitTime as reported in the activation results dropped dramatically as a result of this change.

@yadavvipinsonu - when running the `openwhisk.yml` playbook, was the "included" `routemgmt` playbook also run and was it successful?

if it was not successful, you can run that `routemgmt.yml` playbook all by itself on this system - assuming the cli was successfully installed, which it seems it was.  from the `ansible` folder, run
```
ansible-playbook -i environments/local routemgmt.yml
```
confirm the `apimgmt` package was installed by the `routemgmt.yml` playbook.  from the `ansible` folder run
```
wsk -i package list --auth `cat files/auth.whisk.system`
```
@daisy-ycguo I have added a folder named licenses to host all the license content, with the references in the LICENSE.txt file.

@cbickel, closing this PR since it looks like we went with https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/pull/3526.
@bbrowning, how many invokers are you using in your test cluster?

I'm not very concerned about the controller caching Java actions. Mostly the action invoke path is used in the controller. With that action invoke API in the controller, only action metadata is cached, which does not include the action code.

@chetanmeh, do you think fetching actions from disk will be faster than fetching them from CouchDB?

>May be we can pin Docker version to one where runc works. As while working on Mac if I need to try/test out any runc related aspect I rely on Vagrant image. So if it works with some older version we can pin Docker to that and keep runc enabled

The problem vagrant is using ubuntu16 and installs latest stable, for example 18.03.0-ce, so the invoker image would need to be rebuild with the matching version.

If you are trying and testing runc related things, then is better to experiment with the latest stable release.

I added docs for this special case, for an user to experiment with runc.

The version we recommend and we currently test in Travis and have it pinned in the invoker is an older version 1.12

I was able to figure out how to increase the size of the disk with a vagrant plugin.

@mdeuser check if the plugin works on windows.

> @chetanmeh, do you think fetching actions from disk will be faster than fetching them from CouchDB?

For our usecase we would be pulling attachments from Azure Blob Storage where latency may be higher (based on my previous experience with S3). Would have a benchmark to compare before proceeding with a disk based cache.
@markusthoemmes If the PG test has passed can this PR be approved and merged?
@dubee Reopening this PR as WIP, as here is an additional Load Test and the ability to test action-related calls.
No longer needed.

I had the same issue. It is about Git and the handling of line endings. Try this to clone the repo:

```
git clone --depth=1 https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk.git openwhisk --config core.autocrlf=input
```

Problem is: Git may checkout the files with CRLF-Endings on Windows and the VM interprets that files as LF-Ended. So the additional CR in front of the LF is interpreted to be part of the auth token.
Windows-Files linked into and interpreted by the Linux-VM üòÉ 

Maybe this should be added to the Quick Start Guide.
moved test files to issue #3555
@dubee PG1 2794 üëç

By far not all of these are test files + the files that actually can be categorized as "test-files" are actually files used by tests (small actions). Do we just need to add an appropriate header to each of those?

@dubee I had 4 regular and 1 blackbox Invokers in that test cluster. But, everyone's results will vary based on hardware, resources allocated to Invokers, disk speed of CouchDB cluster, network speed, etc.

would an update to https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/blob/master/.gitattributes be the permanent fix?
```
ansible/files/auth.guest text eol=lf
ansible/files/auth.whisk.system text eol=lf
```

Hi @mdeuser  @akrabat @rabbah @jthomas @jcrossley3 

We are trying to install and use openwhisk in corporate environment. 
Cent-OS is the preferred operating system that we want to use. 

Is there any documentation , webpages that have all the steps in detail for the installation process. 
It seems api functions (api list ,create) are not working when we tried installation through below links

1. https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk
2. https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk-devtools
3. https://blog.krugazor.eu/2017/12/openwhisk-centos-installation-part-2/

Note the reason for suggesting a different URI (vs a header) is for general convenience. Often when firing a webhook configuring the http request with a custom header is not part of the available feature set from the source. 

In general calling this a trigger may suggest one can attach a rule and get 1-n broadcasting. So we‚Äôre carefully considering here that this is a 1-1 case to async invoke the webaction only for now. 

No custom codes/response or rules, yet.

SGTM, but suggest to use /api/v1/async or /api/v1/web-async instead of /api/v1/hook
As you explained yourself, web hooks are different concepts. Even more, one can use the existing web actions as web hooks (we do that in our deployment) - so calling only the async version "hook" is confusing IMHO.
@rabbah, @markusthoemmes, thoughts on this one? Seems like there's a fairly nice performance boost for invoking Java actions.
If we are trying to reflect the Swift Client SDK repo "https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk-client-swift" then we should clarify.
Can you exclude the caching only in the controller? Otherwise, yes this is worth having until we have the more general streaming support.
The other relevant bit is https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/issues/219#issuecomment-272951007 but there isn't any progress yet as far as I know on this.
@mdeuser updated the readme with your comments.
@cbickel @sven-lange-last any updates on this?

Yeah I was not sure what to use in url, went back and forth 

/web/hook/guest/...
/web/trigger/guest/...
/web/async/guest/...
/web-async/guest/...
/async/guest/...

We could s/web/trigger with the implicit trigger for a webaction - and a future enhancement to have first class triggers for 1-n broadcast. 

Edit: I take it back, this would require an ambiguous record fetch from the datastore which we don‚Äôt support. 

It might also be desirable to provide a call back or Id to separately poll for a result. Maybe I‚Äôm feature creeping now. Or thinking some more: a mechanism to decouple the execution of a composition from terminating the http request.

You can always use the same placement constraints for black box and
managed. I just thought someone might find it useful to corral their black
box containers separately, unrelated to resource requirements.

Currently there is no notion of actions requiring specific resources other
than memory(I think?), which is a separate problem.

Is that what you mean?

@rabbah shoo shoo you are feature creeping üòÇ 

One aspect is I would to reserve /triggers/guest... for public/web triggers

This issue then is more descriptive as a plain simple Web action async
To have consistency parsing url segment I would go with one segment

With final proposal for web action async to be /web-async/guest...

To summarize:
/api/v1/web/guest/... (Today‚Äôs Web action sync blocking invoke)
/api/v1/web-async/guest/... (New Web Action Async this issue)
/api/v1/trigger/guest/... (New Web Trigger, new issue to be created to cover this)

Maybe repurpose https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/issues/1805 for the "trigger" part?

I admit I'm feature creeping - so ignore the musing for now.... there is something potentially more general here: if you're executing a sequence or composition, today the HTTP termination is tied to the result of the composition. The web-async is decoupling the HTTP termination from the activation result, and so provides a fire and forget mechanism. It is elegant because it can be done entirely in the controller.

It is restrictive on the flip side, since it doesn't however provide a way to call back/provide an id for decoupled polling (in other words, the async web action returns `Unit`, but the thought of returning a `Promise[Any]` is intriguing).
This task is now done with #3517.

> Currently there is a ignored test count with skip in ArtifactStoreQueryBehaviors as it fails for CouchDB

Opened #3560 to track this

Thanks @tysonnorris .

Provided we leave these 2 settings for now, I'm wondering if the blackbox ratio setting in the controller must be updated to correctly match the VMs allocated for blackbox when using _different_ placement constraints ? For example, given a cluster with `100` VMs, out of which `30` VMs have special attributes for running blackbox actions, should the ratio config in the controller be updated as well to `0.3` ?

This is fixed now
https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/pull/3546
https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/pull/3561

How would you update the blackbox ratio? That ratio only applies to invokers, not the agents running action containers (which may or may not overlap with invokers at all). 

The contstraints would enable you to either:
- run actions only on invokers, then yes the constraints should ideally match the blackbox ratio 
- run actions on invokers, on other non-invoker agents, or a mix, then constraints has no relation to blackbox ratio
I think this is fixed now with the recent updates, please try again

This is fixed now
https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/pull/3561

Yeah you can vagrant ssh and deploy your actions, create trigger and rules use the wsk inside the Vagrant VM.

Another alternative is to use the wsk CLI from outside and configure the CLI to use the Vagrant IP address, the doc has more details https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/blob/master/tools/vagrant/Vagrantfile

But I would recommend to use the wsk and test inside the Vagrant VM, edit your files outside and share the files into the VM with a share folder,

There was something weird with how to read env variables in Vagrant that I had to use lower case `cloudant` and then exported as upper case `Cloudant` in Vagrant script
```
        if [[ $OW_DB == "cloudant" ]]; then
          export OW_DB="Cloudant"
          export OW_DB_PROTOCOL="https"
          export OW_DB_HOST="$OW_DB_USERNAME.cloudant.com"
          export OW_DB_PORT="443"
        else
          export OW_DB="CouchDB"
          export OW_DB_PROTOCOL=#{ENV['OW_DB_PROTOCOL']}
          export OW_DB_HOST=#{ENV['OW_DB_HOST']}
          export OW_DB_PORT=#{ENV['OW_DB_PORT']}
        fi
```

The docs are correct.

Just making sure we cover all options: was the query param `async=true` considered as well? 

On the `/trigger`: does the proposal suggest it should work with both ‚Äútriggers‚Äù and ‚Äúwebactions‚Äù, or limit it to ‚Äúwebactions‚Äù only ?

in a slack chat Carlos brought up the query parameter but we found that it could be ambiguous since it can be an parameter intended for the action itself.  iirc he also suggested a privileged name such as __OW_ASYNC.

On /trigger my inclination is to support it only on webactions today (with an implicit trigger and rule - any webaction can be invoked in this way, asynchrinously, without creating a trigger or rule), but this will cause ambiguity later if we allow real triggers to be named so I think my suggestion was not well thought out at the time.

@kpavel For some of my work I need support for #3477 and was looking for way to extend the environment variables passed. I believe approach taken in this PR (of building env first and then passing it to docker module) is the way forward for #3477 also. 

Any thoughts if such a requirement can be addressed as part of this PR?. Or I can wait for this one to be merged and build up on that
This done I believe.
Done.

don't see any obvious kube problems; it should smoothly pick up the default from application.conf.  I've manually skipped calling collectLogs for performance analysis before, so that should be fine too.

@tysonnorris The idea behind this:
1. Optimization
2. You're able to disable logging for certain actions at **runtime**.

Min and Std values are used to control the bounds + default behavior of the system. You can set Std to 1Meg, then every action created by a user will get only 1 megabyte, but it'll still allow you to go upto Max.
